School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Tianjin University Tianjin 300072 China 1 These authors contributed equally to this manuscript. The silica-to-alumina ratio (SAR) effect on lean methane oxidation over Pd/Beta catalysts was investigated. Light-off test, steady-state performance and kinetic analysis demonstrate the activity of Pd/Beta catalysts shows a volcano-shaped dependence on SAR. Pd/Beta402 presents the highest activity among all samples, regardless of the presence of water. By the employment of H2-TPR, CO-chemisorption, STEM-EDS, TGA and NH3-TPD, it is found that the activity of Pd/Beta catalysts is essentially influenced by their acidity, which is the nature of the SAR effect on methane oxidation. Increasing SAR leads to lower acidity, resulting in less formation of inactive Pd2+ and higher hydrophobicity which benefit methane oxidation. However, the larger PdO particles are formed at the same time, leading to a decrease in the amount of exposed PdO which is detrimental to methane oxidation. This work can guide the design of state-of-the-art zeolite-supported Pd-based methane oxidation catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methane oxidation Pd/Beta Silica-to-alumina ratio effect Acidity Hydrophobicity Exposed PdO Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The number of compressed natural gas (CNG)-fueled vehicles worldwide has increased rapidly in the past decade due to the environmental benefits and financial incentives [1–3]. Meanwhile, unburned methane (CH4), the primary component of CNG-fueled vehicle exhaust, is a potent greenhouse gas, of which the global warming potential over 100 years period is 21 times greater than that of carbon dioxide [2]. The abatement of methane emissions can be achieved by either oxidation catalysts or three-way catalysts, depending on the combustion conditions of engines. Compared with stoichiometric engines equipped with three-way catalysts, lean-burn engines with oxidation catalysts offer a better fuel economy and a more effective after-treatment strategy. Pd-based catalysts are considered the most effective methane oxidation catalysts [4,5]. Pd/Al2O3, which is the most prevalent methane oxidation catalyst, has been proven to be effective in converting methane into harmless carbon dioxide and water [1,4], but it often suffers from water inhibition due to the large amount of water vapor in the exhaust [6,7]. Accumulation of surface hydroxyl groups is widely considered to account for water inhibition [8,9]. To improve the activity of Pd-based catalysts in the presence of water, numerous strategies have been explored, including support modification [10,11], promoter addition [12–14] and core-shell structure [15–17]. A promising approach to developing water-resistant Pd-based catalysts in practical application is using zeolite supports, such as Beta [18–20], SSZ-13 [20,21], silicalite-1 [15,16,22] and so on [6,23], which benefit from their its hydrophobicity, large surface area, high thermal stability, abundant acid sites and wide range of adjustable SAR. Beta zeolite, in particular, has attracted much attention in the field of complete methane oxidation. The SAR of zeolites is a critical factor in determining the methane oxidation activity of zeolite-supported Pd-based catalysts, while the framework structures of zeolites have less impact [6]. However, the influence of SAR on methane oxidation over Pd/Beta zeolite catalysts is not consistent in different studies. Friberg et al. [20] suggested that Pd supported on a highly siliceous Beta zeolite exhibited higher and more stable methane conversion than that supported on Beta zeolite with low SAR or Al2O3 in the presence of water, which correlated to their hydrophobicity. However, only three points of SAR were investigated in their study. Okumura et al. [24] reported Pd/Beta zeolite catalysts with higher SAR were more active for methane oxidation in the presence of water, which attributed to the hydrophobic character of support and the formation of agglomerated PdO. In another work conducted by Losch et al. [23], mesoporous Beta with a medium SAR of 40 was a very competitive stream-resistant methane oxidation catalyst support rather than highly siliceous Beta zeolite. In addition, Wang [15] and Zhang [16] reported the Pd/silicalite-1 catalysts prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method were inefficient in catalytic methane oxidation, although the silicalite-1 support was highly hydrophobic. Furthermore, although the hydrophobicity character of a catalyst is important in catalytic methane oxidation, it remains unclear what factors determine the hydrophobicity of a catalyst. The quantification of the hydrophobicity is also an issue. These contradictions and uncertainties remind us that the SAR effect has not been well understood yet. Besides, the SAR effect on the interaction between PdO and Beta supports is also of much concern, as PdO is the active species of methane oxidation [1,4,8,21,25–27]. Okumura et al. [28] studied the support effect of Pd/zeolite catalysts on methane oxidation activity. They revealed that the degree of the interaction between PdO and acid sites of zeolites played a crucial role in anchoring PdO. In detail, decreasing acidity (increasing SAR) resulted in the growth of PdO particles based on their EXAFS spectra, leading to a decrease in methane oxidation activity. Zhang et al. [18] prepared the highly dispersed PdO nanoparticles that strongly interacted with Beta support through the combination of in-situ Pd reduction and support dealumination, which were highly active for methane conversion. Niu et al. [22] also use an in-situ method to encapsulate 0.123 wt% Pd clusters in the silicalite-1 zeolite, achieving high performance for low-concentration methane oxidation. In a work conducted by Lim et al. [29], the strong interaction between PdO and SSZ-13 zeolite framework played a key role in suppressing PdO sintering and dealumination during methane oxidation, which contributed to excellent activity and durability in the presence of 10% H2O. Park et al. [30] revealed that the medium-pore Pd/H-TNU-10 catalyst with highly dispersed PdO particles existing within the TNU-10 pores showed higher activity and durability for wet methane oxidation than large-pore Pd/H-beta and Pd/H-USY where most of PdO existed as large particles on their outer crystallite surface. All these studies demonstrate the importance of the interaction between PdO and support. Although PdO is active for methane oxidation, inactive Pd2+ usually exists close to Bronsted acid sites of zeolites [21], especially for Beta supports with low SAR. In another work conducted by Chen et al. [19], inactive Pd2+ could be reduced by incorporating Co into Beta support, occupying the ion-exchange sites and leading to more PdO nanocluster formation, which substantially boosted the methane oxidation activity. Methane oxidation was considered to be a structure-sensitive reaction over Pd-based catalysts [31,32]. The Pd states, which are strongly dependent on SAR, should be further investigated from the metal-support interaction perspective in the field of catalytic methane oxidation. In this work, we prepared a series of supported Pd/Beta catalysts with different SAR and systematically examined their activity for lean methane oxidation in the absence and presence of water. Our results show that the catalysts with different SAR present different methane oxidation activity and the reaction feeds also have a significant influence. Analysis of the physical structures and chemical properties by the employment of H2-TPR, STEM-EDS and TGA demonstrates the amount of Pd2+ and PdO, the size of PdO particles and the hydrophobicity vary with SAR, which accounts for the variation in catalyst activity. By correlating the above results and NH3-TPD characterization, we find that the acidity of the catalysts plays a decisive role in the Pd states and the hydrophobicity of the catalysts. The nature of the SAR effect on the methane oxidation activity of Pd/Beta catalysts is also discussed based on the above results. The SAR effect over Pd/Beta catalysts can extend to other zeolite-supported Pd-based methane oxidation catalysts and provide implications for efficient catalyst design. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Beta supports with different SAR were prepared through an oxalic acid dealumination method, with the precursor of commercial H-Beta zeolite (Wuxi Weifu Environmental Catalysts Co., Ltd., China). For example, a 5 g commercial H-Beta zeolite was dispersed in 100 mL oxalic acid aqueous solution (2 mol L−1) preheated to 70 °C, followed by isothermally stirring for 5 h. After that, the solid was separated from the solution by centrifugation and washed with another 100 mL of deionized water. The filter cake was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 12 h and then transferred into a muffle furnace to calcine at 500 °C for 5 h in flowing air. The SAR of the as-prepared Beta support was 402 (determined by ICP-OES in the following) and therefore it was denoted as Beta402. Beta supports with other SAR can be seen in Table S1. In addition, commercial Beta (no dealumination, SAR = 32) was also dried and calcined in the same way. All the supported Pd catalysts were prepared by a widely used incipient-wetness impregnation method using Pd(NH3)4(NO3)2 solution (Kunming Sino-Platinum Metals Catalyst Co., Ltd., China) as the Pd precursor. After loading Pd, the samples were placed at room temperature for 24 h to allow slow water evaporation, dried in a 100 °C oven for another 24 h, and finally calcined in air at 600 °C for 3 h. The nominal Pd loading was 0.5 wt%. To distinguish different samples, the as-prepared Pd/Beta catalysts were hereinafter denoted as Pd/BetaX (where X is SAR). Therefore, our samples included seven catalysts, Pd/Beta32, Pd/Beta90, Pd/Beta266, Pd/Beta402, Pd/Beta498, Pd/Beta750, Pd/Beta1178. 2.2 Activity test and kinetic analysis The activity of Pd/Beta catalysts for dry or wet methane oxidation was evaluated on a home-built apparatus. The catalyst was pelleted and sieved out to 60–80 mesh for further use. Specifically, a 100 mg sample diluted with 900 mg quartz sand was fixed between two sections of quartz wool in a packed-bed tubular reactor with a diameter of 1.2 cm. The catalysts were tested as the following procedures: first, the reactor was ramped up to 500 °C in a 5%O2/N2 flow and held for 30 min. The total gas flow rate was 500 mL min−1 and kept constant throughout the experiment. Second, the reactor was cooled down to 200 °C in a N2 flow to purge excess O2 and held constant before further testing. After that, a simulated reaction gas ([CH4] = 2000 ppm, [O2] = 5%, [H2O] = 0% or 8%, balanced with N2, flow rate = 500 mL min−1, GHSV = 36,000 h−1) was switched over into the reactor. After the reaction feed stream was stable again, the light-off test was initiated up to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 at atmospheric pressure. The light-off test procedure was repeated twice to evaluate the catalyst activity. The exhaust temperature of lean CNG engines was generally below 600 °C [7,27] and the thermodynamic decomposition of PdO above 750 °C [33] was limited in this work. Meanwhile, the steady-state conversion rate at 450 °C was also measured after the same pretreatment procedure as the light-off test because the effect of water inhibition on methane oxidation over Pd catalyst was usually considered to occur below 450 °C [7,34]. All catalysts were tested in the same simulated reaction gas ([CH4] = 2000 ppm, [O2] = 5%, [H2O] = 0% or 8%, balanced with N2, flow rate = 500 mL min−1, GHSV = 36,000 h−1) and the duration was two hours. The methane conversion was calculated as follows: Methane conversion = ([CH4]in – [CH4]out)/ [CH4]in* 100%. To objectively compare the activity of different catalysts, [CH4]out referred to the average methane concentration over the last twenty minutes for each sample. The concentrations of CH4, CO, CO2 and H2O were monitored using a MKS 2030 gas cell and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. To be brief, r dry and r wet were used to represent the steady-state methane conversion rate at 450 °C in the absence and presence of water, respectively. For kinetic analysis, the mass transport limitation was excluded by changing the particle size or GHSV and the heat transport limitation was excluded by controlling the methane conversion below 15% and diluting the samples with quartz sand at a weight ratio of 1:9 based on the best catalyst Pd/Beta402. The activity of the catalysts was tested at 10 °C intervals and the methane conversion was calculated as described above. Arrhenius curves were obtained by plotting the reaction rate against the inverse of temperature and the apparent activation energies were also reported. Besides, TOF was calculated as the following: TOF = R W , where R is the methane conversion rate, μmol CH4 gcat −1 s−1, and W is the amount of exposed PdO, μmol gcat −1. 2.3 Characterization The contents of Pd, Si and Al elements were determined by an inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES, Plasma 1500, NCS). Pore structure was analyzed by N2 physisorption at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. Befoe the N2 adsorption experiment, all Pd/Beta samples were degassed for 12 h at 300 °C under a vacuum to remove any remaining adsorbate. X-Ray powder diffraction was conducted on a Bruker D8 Focus equipped with Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). All patterns were collected at a scanning rate of 0.2° min−1 at 40 kV and 30 mA. The relative crystallinity was calculated based on the peak at 22.5°. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) were performed on a JEOL operating at 200 kV. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was run on a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 instrument equipped with a TCD detector. Particularly, a 100 mg catalyst was fixed in a U-shaped quartz tube. The catalyst was pre-oxidized for 30 min at 500 °C in a 5%O2/N2 flow. It was cooled down to − 80 °C with the help of a cryocooler in an inert Ar flow to purge excess O2 and then held for 10 min. After that, the gas was changed into a 30 mL min− 1 10%H2/Ar flow. When the TCD signal was stable, the sample was ramped to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1, during which H2 consumption was recorded by the TCD. CO chemisorption measurements were conducted on the same equipment. The test procedure was as follows: First, about 100 mg catalyst fixed in a U-shaped quartz tube was pre-oxidized for 30 min at 500 °C in a 5%O2/N2 flow. Second, it was cooled down to 90 °C in an Ar flow and then held for 10 min. Third, the catalyst was reduced in 10%H2/Ar at 90 °C for 10 min after purging excess O2. To quantify the exposed PdO while excluding the influence of cationic Pd2+ which was proved to be inactive in methane oxidation [21], the reduction temperature was fixed at 90 °C according to H2-TPR results, where only PdO was reduced and PdHx decomposition was complete. A short period of reduction time was used to avoid the mobility of Pd as much as possible. After removing the excess H2 with an inert He gas flow and cooling down to 30 °C, pulses of 5%CO/He were injected into the reactor and the TCD readings were recorded. Between each CO pulse injection, there was a 2 min interval to purge the physisorbed CO and the volume of each CO pulse is 0.5162 mL. As both metallic Pd and isolated Pd2+ can adsorb CO, the total adsorbed CO volume can be divided into two parts: the CO volume adsorbed by exposed metallic Pd which was generated from PdO reduction and the CO volume adsorbed by isolated Pd2+. 1:1 for Pd:CO adsorption molar ratio was adopted for both isolated Pd2+ and metallic Pd to calculate the amount of exposed metallic Pd, which was equal to that of exposed PdO. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted on a Mettler-Toledo Thermal Analysis instrument to quantify the water uptake of the catalysts, which reflected the hydrophobicity of the catalysts. In detail, the catalysts were first oxidized for 30 min at 500 °C in a 5%O2/N2 flow, and then quickly transferred into a low-temperature humidity chamber. The catalysts adsorbed water to a saturation under 80% humidity at 70 °C. Excess water vapor was completely removed at 70 °C until the catalyst weight no longer changed. The weight loss curves were obtained by heating the catalysts at 10 °C min−1 on the TGA instrument. NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was conducted on the same equipment as the activity test experiment. After oxidizing the catalysts for 30 min at 500 °C in a 5%O2/N2 flow and cooling down to 100 °C in a N2 flow, a mixed gas flow ([NH3] = 500 ppm, balanced with N2, flow rate = 500 mL min−1) was switched over into the reactor and NH3 adsorption was completed after 2 h at 100 °C. Whereafter, at the constant temperature, physisorbed NH3 was purged with a N2 flow. The reactor was ramped up to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 and the concentrations of desorbed NH3 were recorded using an MKS 2030 gas cell and Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance evaluation The kinetic analysis, along with T50 and r dry(wet) (the steady-state methane conversion rate at 450 °C), in the absence and presence of water are shown in Fig. 1. For kinetic analysis, to ensure all tests were in the kinetic regime, the GHSV was set to 126,000 h−1 and the particle diameter was set to 0.13 mm according to Fig. S1. Meanwhile, the methane conversions were controlled below 15% in the kinetic tests. All conversion data used for kinetic analysis, together with kinetic rates and TOFs, can be found in Table S2. Detailed apparent activation energies and pre-exponential factors are collected in Table S3. The overall light-off and on-stream stability curves can be found in Fig. S2 and Fig. S3, respectively. In the absence of water (Fig. 1a), the performance of Pd/Beta catalysts shows volcano-shaped dependence on the SAR. Pd/Beta402 shows the highest kinetic rates among all samples. All Pd/Beta catalysts show the same apparent activation energy (E app = 79 ∼ 85 kJ mol−1) in the 0% H2O feed (Fig. 1a), indicating methane oxidation follows the same mechanism over Pd/Beta with different SAR. Our E app is consistent with that reported by Lim [29]. The conclusion can be also drawn from Fig. S4a, where the variation of TOF with temperature for Pd/Beta catalysts with different SAR is essentially in a straight line. However, Arrhenius curves in Fig. 1a show that the pre-exponential factors are obviously different between these samples, indicating the number of active sites is different. Detailed data in Table S3 reveals that the pre-exponential factor also shows a volcano-shaped dependence on SAR. We can infer that the number of active sites should also vary in a volcanic pattern with SAR. In our experiment, methane was completely oxidized to carbon oxide, and no carbon monoxide or carbon deposition was detected, indicating partial oxidation or thermal cracking of methane did not occur. 8% H2O was induced into the catalytic system to evaluate the water resistance of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 1b. Kikuchi et al. [35] studied the influence of water concentrations on methane oxidation over oxide-supported Pd catalysts. They found methane oxidation was inhibited even in the presence of 1% water in the feed. A higher water concentration led to a stronger inhibition effect on methane oxidation. The maximum activity difference when changing the water concentrations seemed to occur below 10% H2O. 8% water is sufficient in this work. The activity of Pd/Beta catalysts still shows volcano-shaped dependence on SAR, which is the same as the case in water-free conditions. Pd/Beta402 still shows the highest kinetic rates among all samples. As shown in Fig. 1b and Table S3, all samples show a higher E app compared with their counterparts in the absence of water. Therefore, the existence of excess water will cause methane oxidation to be more difficult to occur. Stotz's work revealed that the presence of water changed the reaction path [8]. In this work, expect for Pd/Beta32 and Pd/Beta90, the other Pd/Beta catalysts show the same apparent activation energy (E app = 167 ∼ 175 kJ mol−1), indicating methane oxidation follows the same mechanism over Pd/BetaX (X ≥ 266). In Fig. S4b, the variation of TOF with temperature for Pd/Beta catalysts with SAR ≥ 266 is also essentially in a straight line, further demonstrating the reaction mechanism is same over these samples. Unfortunately, the low-siliceous Pd/Beta32 and Pd/Beta90 show much lower TOFs compared with other samples. The pre-exponential factor in Table S3 shows a volcano-shaped dependence on SAR. Pre-exponential factors of Pd/Beta32 and Pd/Beta90 are much lower than those of other samples. In a word, based on kinetic analysis, we can conclude that the activity of Pd/Beta catalysts varies in a volcanic pattern with SAR, regardless of the presence of water. The conclusion is also supported by light-off tests and steady-state performance in Fig. 1c, d, Fig. S2 and Fig. S3, where Pd/Beta402 shows the lowest T50 and highest r dry(wet) among all samples. Similar to Murata et al.'s work [36], Pd/Beta402 also shows the highest water resistance (the value of r wet/r dry) among all samples according to Fig. S5. Table S4 lists the most competitive Pd-based catalysts for complete methane oxidation in different studies [18–20,37,38]. Generally, the activity of Pd-based catalysts is greatly influenced by Pd weight percent, space velocity, preparation methods and even reaction feeds (e.g., water concentration and the volume ratio of methane to oxygen). Our Pd/Beta402 sample shows a reasonable T50 value given the use of a low Pd weight percent (0.5 wt%) and a high space velocity (GHSV = 36,000 h−1 or WHSV = 300,000 mL g−1 h−1). In addition, all the samples were carefully tested in the same condition in our experiments. That is, the performance evaluation in this work is reliable to reveal the SAR effect on methane oxidation over Pd/Beta catalysts. 3.2 Textural properties and characterizations 3.2.1 Physical properties of Pd/Beta catalysts For Beta zeolite, aluminum can be removed by oxalic acid leaching via a two-step mechanism that involves the hydrolysis and subsequent chelation process [39]. A series of Beta supports with different SAR were successfully prepared by controlling the concentration of oxalic acid and the time of dealumination (Table S1). Within the first hour, dealumination occurs rapidly, with 86% of the Al being removed (Fig. S6). During the subsequent period, the dealumination becomes much slower, indicating the difference in the resistance ability of different Al atoms. XRD patterns in Fig. S7 confirm the BEA structure of Beta is maintained after dealumination. The crystallinity of dealuminated Beta supports slightly decreases compared to that of Beta32 (Table S5). The peak around 22.5°, corresponding to d 302 of Beta, has shifted to higher 2θ for dealuminated samples compared to that of Beta32, which is attributed to the removal of framework Al and the resulting contraction of Beta crystal lattice [18,39]. The dealumination process of Beta is well controlled and has little effect on the framework structure of Beta zeolite in this work. Table 1 summarizes the physical properties of supported Pd/Beta catalysts. Actual Pd loading, as determined by ICP-OES analysis, is close to the nominal value of 0.5 wt%. Pore structure analysis shows a slight increase in the BET surface area and pore volume for dealuminated Pd/Beta samples compared to pristine Pd/Beta32 (Fig. S8 and S9). It is believed that dealumination leads to the formation of localized defects, therefore increasing in surface area and pore volume of Pd/Beta [40]. Interestingly, the number of pores with a pore width between 3 and 9 nm increases significantly with SAR, as shown in the inset in Fig. S10. Note that the micropore distribution is based on the Horvath-Kawazoe model, while the mesopore distribution is based on the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda model. In addition, all Pd/Beta samples are characterized by a mean micropore width of 0.4 nm. From the XRD patterns presented in Fig. 2, it is found that two main diffraction peaks (2θ = 7.8° and 22.5°) present negligible changes compared with those in Fig. S7, indicating the Pd loading procedure did not damage the BEA structure of Beta. The crystallinity of dealuminated Pd/Beta catalysts shows a slight decrease (Table S5) compared with that of Pd/Beta32. Unfortunately, the overlap in diffraction peaks between PdO and BEA structure around 33° makes the peaks of PdO indiscernible for all Pd/Beta catalysts. However, the lack of the peak at 40°, which corresponds to the typical diffraction peak of metallic Pd, indicates almost no metallic Pd exists. The forms in which Pd species exist will be further discussed in H2-TPR analysis. As a whole, Pd/Beta catalysts with different SAR were successfully prepared in this work and the insignificant changes in physical structures are not considered to influence the catalyst activity. 3.2.2 Pd states To determine the states of the Pd component, H2-TPR was conducted, as shown in Fig. 3. To avoid PdO reduction by H2 at room temperature, the initial temperature was set at − 80 °C. In Fig. 3, peak α is attributed to PdO reduction by H2 and peak β is attributed to the decomposition of PdHx [41]. The area difference between peak α and peak β, corresponding to the amount of total PdO (Table 1), increases gradually with increasing SAR. The amount of total PdO is highest for Pd/Beta1178, approximately twice that of Pd/Beta32. Our results demonstrate highly siliceous Beta facilitates the formation of PdO. The peak γ between 130 °C and 190 °C is attributed to the reduction of isolated Pd2+, which is located close to Bronsted acid sites of the Beta framework structure [41]. The amount of Pd2+ decreases gradually with increasing SAR (Table 1), almost reaching zero over Pd/Beta750 and Pd/Beta1178. As dealumination proceeds, fewer acid sites are available for Pd2+ to locate, resulting in the formation of more PdO particles. Particularly, for each sample, the sum of the amount of total PdO and the amount of Pd2+ determined by H2-TPR is close to the corresponding actual Pd loading determined by ICP-OES, indicating almost all Pd over these samples exists in the form of either PdO or Pd2+, which confirms XRD results. It is no wonder almost no metallic Pd exists since all the samples were calcined at 600 °C for 3 h in air. The temperature of peak α also increases with an increasing SAR of Pd/Beta catalysts, as shown more clearly in Table S6. The higher the temperature is, the more difficult for PdO to be reduced. In the work conducted by Li et al. [42], two H2 consumption peaks were observed over the prepared Pd/SiO2/cordierite monolith catalyst and they suggested the peak at the higher temperature was attributed to the reduction of larger PdO particles. That is, larger PdO particles were more difficult to be reduced. In our work, the increasing temperature center of peak α reflects the fact that the size of PdO particles increases with increasing SAR of Pd/Beta catalysts. In addition, all Pd/Beta samples show a symmetrical and sharp peak α, indicating the narrow size distribution of PdO particles. More details, including temperature center values and the corresponding H2 quantity for peak α, β and γ, are summarized in Table S6. STEM was employed to analyze the size distribution of PdO particles across different Pd/Beta catalysts, as shown in Fig. 4. For each sample, at least 300 particles were statistically analyzed. The average size of PdO particles gradually increases with increasing SAR, which is consistent with H2-TPR results. Clear agglomeration of PdO can be seen over Pd/Beta750 and Pd/Beta1178, with an average particle size of 6.3 nm and 8.0 nm, respectively. On the contrary, well-dispersed PdO particles can be found over Pd/Beta32 and Pd/Beta90. As for Pd/Beta266, Pd/Beta402 and Pd/Beta498, they show a similar particle size distribution between 4 nm and 5 nm. Note that the scale is different for different samples. To further demonstrate the different dispersion of PdO particles over different Pd/Beta catalysts, the EDS analysis was carried out. Three representative samples, Pd/Beta90, Pd/Beta402 and Pd/Beta1178, were chosen for the analysis, of which EDS images are displayed in Fig. 5. Large PdO particles can be found over Pd/Beta1178, while PdO particles were well dispersed over Pd/Beta90 and Pd/Beta402. Interestingly, the brightness variation of a majority of Pd atoms coincides with that of Al atoms, indicating some PdO or Pd2+ are located surrounding the Al sites. The ring-like distribution of Pd atoms may be due to different Al sites in the framework structure of Beta. The relationship between PdO particle size and SAR of Pd/Beta samples is shown in Fig. S11. The agglomeration of PdO becomes more severe when SAR > 402. Combined H2-TPR and STEM-EDS analysis have identified the existence of well-dispersed PdO or Pd2+ over Pd/Beta catalysts with low SAR and large PdO particles over Pd/Beta with high SAR. As Pd2+ is inactive for methane oxidation [21], it will no longer be the focus of this work. 3.2.3 Hydrophobicity and acidity The quantification of the hydrophobicity is an issue that needs to be addressed. Losch et al. [23] measured the amount of water uptake at 100 °C to quantify the hydrophilicity of different supports. Further H2O-TPD experiments demonstrated ZSM-5 and γ-Al2O3 retained more water than mesoporous Beta when methane oxidation was running (T > 300 °C). Murata et al. [36] also used H2O-TPD to measure the desorption of OH/H2O species on Al2O3 with different crystalline phases. Quantitative analysis revealed that the amount of desorbed H2O per gram of Al2O3 was in the order α-Al2O3 < θ-Al2O3 < γ-Al2O3, which well reflected their hydrophobicity. Here, we developed another facile method to quantify the hydrophobicity of different Pd catalysts by measuring the weight loss of samples at elevated temperatures on the TGA instrument, which avoided the adsorption of water on equipment pipes. The detailed experimental procedures are described above. Fig. 6 presents the weight loss curves and corresponding water uptake of all Pd/Beta catalysts. Note that the water uptake in Fig. 6b corresponds to the weight loss from the initial temperature (70 °C) to 450 °C, since water inhibition on Pd-based methane oxidation catalysts occurs below 450 °C [7,34]. It is clear that the amount of water uptake gradually decreases with increasing SAR. Three periods of weight loss can be observed in Fig. 6a. The weight loss below 150 °C should be attributed to physisorbed or occluded water molecules [43]. At the temperature between 150 °C and 500 °C, chemisorbed water molecules begin to desorb as temperature increases. Further increasing temperature beyond 500 °C will lead to dihydroxylation [44], especially for Pd/Beta32 and Pd/Beta90. NH3-TPD was conducted to determine the acidity of Pd/Beta catalysts, of which results are shown in Fig. 7. The peak α and β lower than 250 °C are attributed to weak acid sites, while peak γ and θ are assigned to strong acid sites [45,46]. It should not be a surprise that the acidity decreases with increasing SAR, especially when SAR changes from 32 to 266. The difference between in the acidity of Pd/Beta catalysts with SAR ≥ 402 is insignificant. 3.3 Investigation of catalyst activity in the absence and presence of water Gas-solid heterogeneous reactions typically occur on the surface of active species, since the gaseous reactants cannot directly contact with bulk species. In this work, the size of PdO particles in different Pd/Beta catalysts resulted in varying levels of PdO exposure. The amount of exposed PdO was determined by CO-chemisorption characterization after reducing the catalysts in 10%H2/Ar flow at 90 °C for 10 min. This temperature ensured that only PdO was reduced to metallic Pd, and the decomposition of PdHx was complete according to H2-TPR results (Fig. 3). A short period of reduction is used to avoid the agglomeration of Pd particles caused by H2 reduction as much as possible. The exposed PdO amount is considered equivalent to that of exposed metallic Pd. The CO adsorption was conducted at 30 °C, at which both metallic Pd and isolated Pd2+ can adsorb CO. Therefore, the specific Pd dispersion in Table 1 represents the ratio of the sum of the amount of exposed PdO and the amount of Pd 2 + the amount of total Pd . The amount of exposed PdO can be calculated by subtracting the amount of Pd2+ from that of Pd determined by CO-chemisorption, which can be found in Table 1. Fig. 8 presents the variation of the amount of total PdO and exposed PdO with SAR. The amount of exposed PdO shows a volcano-shaped dependence on SAR, with the highest point corresponding to Pd/Beta402, with an exposed PdO amount of 37.1 μmol gcat −1. When SAR > 402, the ratio of the amount of exposed PdO to that of total PdO decreases significantly, further demonstrating the size of PdO particles over these samples increases with increasing SAR. As for samples with SAR < 402, the average size of PdO is about 3 ∼ 5 nm, resulting in little difference in the ratio, but the formation of more Pd2+ results in fewer total PdO and thus exposed PdO over these samples. CO-chemisorption results are consistent with H2-TPR and STEM-EDS results. Methane is activated and oxidized through a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism over PdO(101) [8]. To investigate the reason why the activity of Pd/Beta catalysts shows a volcano-shaped dependence on SAR which has been demonstrated above, we use R dry, 330 ℃ (the average reaction rate at 330 °C in the absence of water, calculated based on kinetic analysis in Table S2) and R wet, 440 ℃ (the average reaction rate at 440 °C in the presence of 8% water, calculated based on kinetic analysis in Table S2) to represent the catalyst activity in the absence and presence of water, respectively. Fig. 9 and Fig. S12 have depicted the relationship between R dry, 330 ℃ or R wet, 440 ℃ and the amount of exposed PdO. The well-fitted correlation between R dry, 330 ℃ and the amount of exposed PdO with R2 = 0.96 in Fig. 9 declares that the catalyst activity is dependent on the amount of exposed PdO in the absence of water, which is consistent with the discussion in 3.1. Performance evaluation. However, the R2 is only 0.78 when plotting R wet, 440 ℃ against the amount of exposed PdO (Fig. S12), which means R wet, 440 ℃ is not only dependent on the amount of exposed PdO. The drastic decrease in R2 in Fig. S12 is mainly because of the discrepancy between Pd/Beta32 or Pd/Beta90 and other samples. Water is a strong inhibitor of lean methane oxidation over Pd-based catalysts [6,7], which is also confirmed in our results (Fig. 1). The hydrophobicity of Pd/Beta32 and Pd/Beta90 catalysts are much lower than the other samples (Fig. 6). Therefore, the above discrepancy between Pd/Beta32 or Pd/Beta90 and other samples should be attributed to the difference in hydrophobicity. Fig. 10 depicts the dependence of R wet, 440 ℃ on the hydrophobicity of catalysts and the amount of exposed PdO over Pd/Beta with different SAR. When SAR ≤ 402, the catalyst activity is strongly inhibited by water vapor, so the influence of the amount of exposed PdO is insignificant and the hydrophilic/hydrophobic character is the key factor in determining the catalyst activity. On the contrary, when Si/Al ≥ 402, the catalyst activity decreases with an increasing SAR although the corresponding hydrophobicity continues to increase. Over these samples, it’s the amount of exposed PdO that plays a decisive role in determining the catalyst activity because the catalysts are already hydrophobic enough. In a word, the volcano-shaped dependence of methane oxidation on SAR over Pd/Beta catalysts in the presence of water is a combined effect of the amount of exposed PdO and the hydrophobicity of catalysts. Our results are not in conflict with those reported by Friberg et al. [20]. Indeed, the r wet of Pd/Beta1178 in our work (4.8 × 10−4 mmol gPd −1 s−1) is at the same order of magnitude as that of Pd/Beta969 (SAR = 969) in their work (about 1.0 × 10−4 mmol gPd −1 s−1). The difference in coefficients is due to the different reaction conditions and SAR. High silicious Pd/Beta can no doubt mitigate the inhibition effect of water because of their excellent hydrophobicity, but also cause the agglomeration of PdO particles and thus the loss of catalyst activity. Therefore, from our perspective, the SAR should be controlled at around 402 for efficient methane oxidation. 3.4 The nature of the SAR effect The activity of Pd/Beta catalysts depends on the amount of exposed PdO and the hydrophobicity of catalysts. The former is a combined result of the amount and particle size of PdO. Decreasing acidity leads to fewer Pd2+, resulting in more PdO. However, supports with lower acidity are more challenging to disperse Pd during the preparation process, leading to the formation of larger PdO particles during air calcination. More importantly, PdO is a basic oxide, which tends to interact with the acid sites existing in the framework of Beta. The weak interaction between PdO and support further contributes to the mobility and aggregation of PdO. As for the hydrophobicity, catalysts with more acid sites are more hydrophilic due to their stronger affinity for water molecules, which is either through the hydrogen bond between Bronsted acid sites and water molecules or the ligand effect between Lewis acid sites and water molecules. The relationship between the amount of Pd2+, total PdO, exposed PdO, the average size of PdO particles, the hydrophobicity and the acidity are shown in Fig. 11. Apparently, increasing acidity leads to a linear increase in the amount of Pd2+ and a linear decrease in the amount of total PdO. However, the nonlinear decrease in the average size of PdO particles with increasing acidity results in a volcano-shaped dependence of the amount of exposed PdO on the acidity. On the other hand, the linear correlation between water uptake and acidity with R2 = 0.97 demonstrates that hydrophobicity is inversely proportional to the acidity of Pd/Beta catalysts. Based on the above analysis, we can conclude that increasing SAR leads to lower acidity. This not only contributes to more PdO and higher hydrophobicity which benefits methane oxidation, but also results in the formation of larger PdO particles which is unfavorable for methane oxidation. The combined effect is considered to be the nature of the SAR effect. 4 Conclusions In this work, the SAR effect on lean methane oxidation over Pd/Beta catalysts was systematically investigated under water-free and 8% water-feed conditions in our work. The activity of Pd/Beta catalysts varies with the SAR in a volcanic pattern and the optimal SAR is 402, both in the absence and presence of water. Without water in the feed, the catalyst activity is dependent on the amount of exposed PdO. Increasing SAR leads to more PdO but subsequent aggregation of PdO particles, which accounts for the volcano-shaped activity curves. With 8% H2O in the feed, the catalyst activity is relevant not only to the amount of exposed PdO, but also to the hydrophobicity of catalysts. Compared with Pd/Beta402, Pd/BetaX (X ＜ 402) is more hydrophilic and less active for methane oxidation, while Pd/BetaX (X ＞ 402) shows lower methane oxidation activity for the same reason as in the absence of water. The acidity of catalysts plays a decisive role in the amount of exposed PdO and the hydrophobicity. Increasing SAR results in lower acidity, which results in less Pd2+, more PdO and higher hydrophobicity that benefits methane oxidation, but larger PdO particles also degrade the catalysts. The combined effect is the nature of SAR effect. Our work shows that catalysts with moderate acidity are effective for methane oxidation in practical applications. coredata.dc:description: The silica-to-alumina ratio (SAR) effect on lean methane oxidation over Pd/Beta catalysts was investigated. Light-off test, steady-state performance and kinetic analysis demonstrate the activity of Pd/Beta catalysts shows a volcano-shaped dependence on SAR. Pd/Beta402 presents the highest activity among all samples, regardless of the presence of water. By the employment of H2-TPR, CO-chemisorption, STEM-EDS, TGA and NH3-TPD, it is found that the activity of Pd/Beta catalysts is essentially influenced by their acidity, which is the nature of the SAR effect on methane oxidation. Increasing SAR leads to lower acidity, resulting in less formation of inactive Pd2+ and higher hydrophobicity which benefit methane oxidation. However, the larger PdO particles are formed at the same time, leading to a decrease in the amount of exposed PdO which is detrimental to methane oxidation. This work can guide the design of state-of-the-art zeolite-supported Pd-based methane oxidation catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: The nature of silica-to-alumina ratio effect on lean methane oxidation over Pd/Beta zeolite catalysts
